(1) Every point can be represented as the corresponding pair of Cartesian coordinates (René Descartes): The Euclidean space R n Introduction The x -axis and y -axes are orthogonal and intersect at the point O(0, 0). Every point is denoted by P, P(x0, y0), P = (x0, y0). The lines of the form x = x0, are parallel to y -axis, and in particular the y -axis itself has the equation y -axis : x = 0. As a set it can be expressed as y -axis = {(0, y ) : y ∈ R}. Similarly the lines y = y0 are parallel to x -axis; horizontal. Then x -axis : y = 0 and x -axis = {(x , 0) : x ∈ R}. The Euclidean plane consists of 4 quadrants. We enumerate from 1 to 4 starting from top-right to bottom-right. The point C is the center of the sphere, and r is its radius. • The interior points are of distance less than r from the centre and the exterior of distance more than r from the centre. The Euclidean space R n Vectors on R n Vectors • The following notion coming from Algebra will be of high importance in our study. • As a vector of R 2 (or R3) we refer to every directional linear segment; u := ⃗u := −→ AB := AB. We refer to the point A as its start and the point B as its end and the size or length of the vector, is exactly the size of the corresponding linear segment, the distance between A and B; |u| := | −→ AB| := |AB|. • Two vectors are equal when they have the same direction and size. This means that we can move (but not rotate) a vector, while keeping it invariant. • Velocity, acceleration, and force are typical examples of vectors. • A vector u = (u1, u2, u3) on R3 (similarly R2) represent the change between the start and end points by u1 (positive/negative) in the first coordinate, u2 in the second and u3 in the third. In other words the vector −→ AB with start at the point A(a1, a2, a3) and end at B(b1, b2, b3) is −→ AB = (b1 − a1, b2 − a2, b3 − a3). It will be very often convenient to identify every point B(x , y ) with the vector −→ OB = (x , y ) = u. Several times we further identify the letters used; point P(x , y ) and vector p = (x , y ), without extra emphasis. The Euclidean space R n Vectors on R n Rn Let n ∈ N. The Euclidean space of dimension n is defined as the set of all points/vectors with n real coordinates: Rn := {x = (x1, . . . , xn) : xi ∈ R, i = 1, . . . , n}. (12) • In particular R 3, R2 and R1 are referred as the Euclidean space, plane and line respectively. • We commonly use (x , y ) and (x , y , z) for the points/vectors of R2 and R 3 respectively. Whenever we are on R2 or R3 the coordinates’ correspondence is x1 = x , x2 = y and x3 = z. • The vector 0 := ⃗0 := (0, . . . , 0) is referred as the zero vector of R n and plays the role of multi-dimensional analogous of the zero real number. The Euclidean space R n Vectors on R n Vector operations; recap from Linear algebra Consider x = (x1, . . . , xn), y = (y1, . . . , yn) ∈ Rn and λ ∈ R. • The vectors x and y are equal, when all of their corresponding coordinates are equal to each other; x = y ⇔ xi = yi , for every i = 1, . . . , n. (13) • Their sum x + y and their difference x − y are the vectors of Rn given below: x + y = (x1 + y1, . . . , xn + yn) x − y = (x1 − y1, . . . , xn − yn). (14) • The opposite vector of x is given by −x := (−x1, . . . , −xn). (15) •The scalar product between λ and x is the vector: λx := (λx1, . . . , λxn). The Euclidean space R n Vectors on R n Vector equation of a line • So far we have seen analytic equations of lines on R 2 and R 3 (as intersections of planes). Vectors can be employed for obtaining further expressions of line equations. • A line passing through the point P(p1, p2, p3) with direction d = (d1, d2, d3) ̸= 0 has the following vector equation: x = p + td, for every t ∈ R. (17) (recall that p = −→ OP = (p1, p2, p3)) Which may represented coordinate-wise as x1 = p1 + td1, x2 = p2 + td2, x3 = p3 + td3, t ∈ R (18) • The equation of a line defined by two different points P(p1, p2, p3), Q(q1, q2, q3) can be obtained as above with d := −→ PQ. • All the above hold exactly in the same way for lines on R n, for every n. Similarly cos(θ) = −1 ⇔ x = λy, for some λ < 0 (parallel and of the opposite direction); i.e. θ = π. Two vectors are called orthogonal when x · y = 0. The zero vector is orthogonal to every vector and when x, y ̸= 0, the angle of two vectors is π/2 if and only if x · y = 0. A vector v ∈ Rn is called a unit vector when ∥v∥ = 1. For every non-zero vector u, the vector v := u/∥u∥ is a unit vector of the same direction. The Euclidean space R n Vectors on R n Standard unit vectors • The standard unit vectors of Rn are the vectors {e1, e2, . . . , en}, where e1 = (1, 0, . . . , 0), e2 = (0, 1, 0, . . . , 0), . . . , en = (0, 0, . . . , 0, 1), (27) (ei has all coordinates 0, but i-th coordinate which is 1). • These are orthogonal to each other; ei · ej = 0, ∀i ̸= j. • Let v = (v1, v2, . . . , vn) ∈ Rn. Then we can express it as a unique linear combination of e1, . . . , en: v = v1e1 + · · · + vnen. (28) • Geometrically the ei vector is the unit vector parallel to the xi -axis in the positive direction. • In the literature, when n = 3, the vectors e1, e2, e3 of R3 may appear as i, j, k respectively. The Euclidean space R n Vectors on R n The cross product on R3 • We restrict on R3 and let e1 = (1, 0, 0), e2 = (0, 1, 0) and e3 = (0, 0, 1) the standard unit vectors. Let a = (a1, a2, a3), b = (b1, b2, b3) ∈ R3. The cross product a × b ∈ R 3 is the vector defined as a × b = ∣ ∣ ∣ ∣ ∣ e1 e2 e3 a1 a2 a3 b1 b2 b3 ∣ ∣ ∣ ∣ ∣ (expand the first row of the determinant) (31) = (a2b3 − a3b2)e1 + (a3b1 − a1b3)e2 + (a1b2 − a2b1)e3. (32) • Let a, b, c ∈ R 3. The real number a · (b × c) is referred as their triple product. It turns out that a · (b × c) = ∣ ∣ ∣ ∣ ∣ a1 a2 a3 b1 b2 b3 c1 c2 c3 ∣ ∣ ∣ ∣ ∣ =: det[a, b, c]. (33) The Euclidean space R n Vectors on R n Interpretation and properties 0 × b = a × 0 = 0, for every a, b ∈ R3. More generally, when a and b are parallel (i.e. a = λb, for some λ ∈ R), then a × b = 0. For instance a × a = 0. The cross product a × b is orthogonal to both a and b. When a and b are not parallel, then a × b is orthogonal to every vector in the plane defined by a and b. a × b = −b × a (anticommutativity). e1 × e2 = e3, e2 × e3 = e1 and e3 × e1 = e2. But e1 × e3 = −e2, etc. ∥a × b∥ = ∥a∥∥b∥| sin(θ)|, where θ = ( ̂a, b) and therefore it is equal with the area of the parallelogram defined by a and b. a × (b + c) = a × b + a × c. (λa) × b = a × (λb) = λ(a × b). The Euclidean space R n Vectors on R n Jacobi identity: a × (b × c) + b × (c × a) + c × (a × b) = 0. (34) Clearly when any two of a, b and c are parallel, a · (b × c) = 0. When there is not any couple of parallel vectors between a, b and c, these are defining a parallelepiped having as edges the vectors a, b and c. This solid is expressed by the set of the following linear combinations: Par(a, b, c) = { u = λa + µb + νc : 0 ≤ λ, µ, ν ≤ 1 } . (35) The volume of the parallelepiped is the absolute value of the triple product, or of the determinant of the three vectors! Vol(Par(a, b, c)) = |a · (b × c)| = |det[a, b, c]| (36) The Euclidean space R n Vectors on R n Example Let a = (0, 3, 4), b = (0, −4, 3) and c = (1, 0, −1) as before.
